awd_titl_txt: Classical Methods in Motivic Homotopy Theory
awd_abstract_narration:
The subject of algebraic geometry concerns itself with the study of systems of polynomial equations.  As it turns out, solving such systems exactly is, apart from a few very special cases, essentially impossible. We thus attempt to describe the solution sets more qualitatively. One classically fruitful approach to this is to consider the set of solutions as a topological space, an object sitting in some higher dimensional space.  For instance, the equation x^2+y^2=1 describes a circle of radius 1.  Topologists have invented invariants for qualitatively describing topological spaces, and we can just attempt to work out these invariants for the special spaces we are interested in. Taking this idea to its extreme, one arrives at a field called motivic homotopy theory. It provides novel ways for qualitatively describing solutions of systems of polynomial equations, and has in the past twenty years been successfully applied to several longstanding open problems in algebraic geometry.  This project aims to deepen our understanding of motivic homotopy theory by exploring further not only its parallels with classical topology, but also what happens where these parallels break down.

This project consists of several parts. One set of parts explores properties of motivic highly structured ring spectra, called normed spectra (introduced in collaboration with M. Hoyois).  The Principal Investigator (P.I.) will (1) study power operations in normed spectra and deduce splitting results for normed spectra of positive characteristic and stability results for the motivic homology of symmetric groups and (2) construct further normed spectra, such as a normed spectrum structure on the motivic spectrum KO representing hermitian K-theory.  Another set of parts explores the passage from unstable to stable motivic homotopy theory. Specifically the P.I. will (3) study the motivic Barratt-Priddy-Quillen map, and (4) study an unstable motivic homology Whitehead theorem.  These goals will be achieved by using techniques from higher category theory, classical stable homotopy theory, algebraic topology and algebraic geometry. The results in parts (1) and (2) can be used to more effectively study algebraic varieties using cohomology theories; for example by exploiting the cohomology operations present in theories represented by normed spectra. Parts (3) and (4) are more useful for studying the motivic (stable) homotopy category itself, and hence the totality of all cohomology theories for algebraic varieties at once.

por.por_cntn:
Mathematics frees us to study geometric objects -- often objects that locally resemble Euclidean space, known as manifolds -- in high dimension. As the dimension increases, the potential complexity of these objects increases exponentially (or faster). Algebra is used to organize this complexity, and the field of algebraic topology is the result. The research undertaken under this grant (by graduate students Adela YiYu Zhang and David Jongwon Lee) lies at the cutting edge of this field of endeavor. 

Zhang's work starts from a simple and traditional question: what is the shape of the space made up of a finite configuration of points on a manifold? Interest in this question goes back many decades, but Zhang's study began with a very recent observation, due to Ben Knudsen (Northeastern University) relating it to an equally classical subject in pure algebra, namely Lie algebras. She brings Knudsen's abstract work down to earth and obtains a variety of concrete and novel computations. 

To be more precise, Knudsen relates configuration spaces to a topological enrichment of the classical notion of Lie algebras, known as "spectral Lie algebras" (whose study was initiated by Michael Ching in his thesis under the direction of the PI). In further work, Zhang's research greatly enhances our understanding of these quite abstract objects. There are payoffs. "Commutative rings" constitute a type of algebraic system with just as much pedigree as Lie algebras, and just as Lie algebras they admit a topological enrichment. Zhang's work leads to a great enhancement of our understanding of the structure of these "spectral rings."


In more recent work, Zhang, together Andy Senger (another former student of the PI), has completed a project whose roots go back sixty years or so: namely, the classification of a natural restricted class of manifolds. This work combines the latest advances in the abstract reaches of algebraic topology with very specific concrete geometric insights. 

David Lee's work has been directed by Professor Jeremy Hahn. He has taken on some of the most competitive challenges in the theoretical sector of algebraic topology. The challenge of enumerating the diverse ways spheres of different dimensions can project onto each other has been a touchstone of the subject for almost a century. Very recent - still unpublished - work of Hahn together with Robert Burklund, MIT graduate student Ishan Levy, and Tomer Schlank (Hebrew University, visiting MIT during 2022-23) has offered profound new insight into certain "asymptotics" of that question, by providing counterexamples to a fifty-year old hypothesis known as the telescope conjecture. These examples open an entirely new area of research. Working with fellow MIT graduate student Ishan Levy, Lee has carried out a key calculation in an alternative approach to these important examples.
